TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit MimeEntity extends System.Object

Docs.summary: An abstract MIME entity.

remarks.para: A MIME entity is really just a node in a tree structure of MIME parts in a MIME message.
There are 3 basic types of entities: , , and (which is actually just a special variation of who's content is another MIME message/document). All other types are derivatives of one of those.

MemberSignature.Value: public Uri ContentBase { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Uri ContentBase

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the base content URI.
Docs.value: The base content URI or null.

remarks.para: The Content-Base header specifies the base URI for the in cases where the is a relative URI.
The Content-Base URI must be an absolute URI.

Docs.exception: is not an absolute URI.

MemberSignature.Value: public MimeKit.ContentDisposition ContentDisposition { get; set; }
.property instance class MimeKit.ContentDisposition ContentDisposition

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the content disposition.
Docs.remarks: Represents the pre-parsed Content-Disposition header value, if present. If the Content-Disposition header is not set, then this property will be null.

MemberSignature.Value: public string ContentId { get; set; }
.property instance string ContentId

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the content identifier.

remarks.para: The Content-Id header is used for uniquely identifying a particular entity and uses the same syntax as the Message-Id header on MIME messages.

Setting a Content-Id allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by its unique identifier, typically by using a "cid:" URI in an HTML-formatted message body. This can be useful, for example, when the HTML-formatted message body needs to reference image attachments.

MemberSignature.Value: public Uri ContentLocation { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Uri ContentLocation

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the content location.

remarks.para: The Content-Location header specifies the URI for a MIME entity and can be either absolute or relative.

Setting a Content-Location URI allows other objects within the same multipart/related container to reference this part by URI. This can be useful, for example, when constructing an HTML message body that needs to reference image attachments.

MemberSignature.Value: public MimeKit.ContentType ContentType { get; }
.property instance class MimeKit.ContentType ContentType

Docs.summary: Gets the type of the content.

remarks.para: The Content-Type header specifies information about the type of content contained within the MIME entity.

MemberSignature.Value: public MimeKit.HeaderList Headers { get; }
.property instance class MimeKit.HeaderList Headers

Docs.summary: Gets the list of headers.
Docs.remarks: Represents the list of headers for a MIME part. Typically, the headers of a MIME part will be various Content-* headers such as Content-Type or Content-Disposition, but may include just about anything.

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual void OnHeadersChanged (MimeKit.HeaderListChangedAction action, MimeKit.Header header);
.method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnHeadersChanged(valuetype MimeKit.HeaderListChangedAction action, class MimeKit.Header header) cil managed

Docs.param: The header being added, changed or removed.
Docs.summary: Called when the headers change in some way.

remarks.para: Whenever a header is added, changed, or removed, this method will be called in order to allow custom subclasses to update their state.
Overrides of this method should call the base method so that their superclass may also update its own state.
